Your site is wonderful! This hymn takes me back to my childhood, growing up in a small town and attending the small church in which I accepted Christ as my Savior at a young age during a revival. That is a memory I will never forget. A friend of mine urged me to go down to the altar and after I was there, on my knees, I felt arms around me, and it was my earthly father, who was crying as I was, and he asked "Son, do you know what you are doing?" and I said yes. Though I strayed over the years, I have always known that God is with me, and that through the Holy Spirit He hears my pleas and prayers, and answers them in His Divine Will. Praise God, praise God!
At a prayer meeting and the song came and I googled it and began to sing. Tears of commitment began to well up in eyes. I felt the presence of the Father afresh.

In prayer and praise just now the words to this beautiful hymn sang through my spirit. I googled the words and began singing with the lyrics. My eyes fell below to the comments and tears began to fill my eyes as I saw person after person with the same experience as mine. Yes, Our God is alive in us and speaks to us if we listen! Praise God and the depths of His love that we cannot yet know!

I am thine by the mercies of God. How reassuring to know that I am going to see my God face to face. All doubts melted. He wants my consecration. I am assured of greater love and joy before I finally go home. The message is loaded. I am grateful to God for this site. Thank you so much.

I am a Catholic priest and choirmaster, but I have loved Fanny Crosby's hymns from my youth. I have always been moved by the story of her reply to someone who asked, if she had her life over, whether she would choose to see. As I remember her reply: "No, sir, I would choose to be blind; for the first thing I shall see, when I get to heaven, is the face of Him who died for me." Her blindness played a significant part in her hymn lyrics. For example, in Blessed Assurance: "Visions of rapture burst on my sight, or To God be the Glory: "...our wonder, our rapture, when Jesus we see!" And, of course, the present hymn: "...Ere thee face to face I see." What a love for the Divine Saviour she had, and to how many people has that love been communicated through her profound lyrics and the melodies of WH Doane.

Fanny wrote this favorite hymn in Cincinatti, OH. She was visiting her friend and collaborator, William H. Doane, in his home. The sun was setting, and their conversation turned to the nearness of God. Crosby was touched by their talk and wrote the words of this hymn before she retired that night. Doane added the music in the morning. It may be that the "friend to friend" communion in the 3rd stanza is an allusion to Crosby's fine friendship with Doane. - Great Songs of Faith by Brown & Norton
